facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 176 of 1960 is an appeal from the judgment and decree dated June 2, 1958, of the Mysore High Court in R. A. No. 268 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated June 2, 1958, of the Mysore High Court in R. A. No. 268 of 1957.

facts.text: The judgment of the Court was delivered on November 14, 1962 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. November 14. The judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-

facts.text: On March 27, 1954, the three Kapurs, who are the respondents, filed original Suit No. 29 of 1954 before the District Judge Bangalore against the 3 appellants who are brothers for the recovery of over Rs. 50,000/- and subsequent interest and costs due on a simple mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: On March 27, 1954, the three Kapurs--who are the respondents before us-filed original Suit No. 29 of 1954 before the District judge Banglore, against the 3 appellants who are brothers for the recovery of over Rs. 50,000/- and subsequent interest and compan

facts.text: Before the suit came on for trial the parties filed a memo of compromise dated September 30, 1955 and prayed that the suit be decreed in terms thereof.

anchor.surface_text: Before the suit came on for trial the parties filed a memo of companypromise dated September 30, 1955 and they prayed that the suit may decreed in terms there of The Court accepted the application and passed a decree as prayed for the order reading

facts.text: The Court accepted the application and passed a decree as per terms of the compromise, the copy of which is annexed.

anchor.surface_text: It is ordered and decreed that the plaintiffs suit be and the same is hereby decreed as per terms of the companypromise, the companyy of which is hereunto annexed.

facts.text: The terms of the Razinama state that the defendants agree to a decree being passed as prayed for.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of the Razinama ran as follows That the defendants herein agree to a decree being passed as prayed for.

facts.text: The mortgaged properties are hereby sold for the amount of the decree in full satisfaction thereof.

anchor.surface_text: That the mortgaged properties are hereby sold for the amount of the decree in full satisfaction thereof.

facts.text: The defendants will execute a regular sale deed within ten days from September 30, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The defendants will execute a regular sale and within ten days from this date.

facts.text: The mortgaged properties are hereby put in possession of the plaintiff decree-holder by the 3rd defendant judgment debtor and judgment debtors 1 and 2 agreeing to pay rent at Rs. 75 each for the two shops bearing Nos. 12 and 14 respectively, Godown Street, Bangalore City.

anchor.surface_text: That the mortgaged properties are hereby put in possession of the plaintiff  decree- holder  by the 3rd, defendant  judgment debtor  and judgment debtors 1 2 agreeing to pay rent at Rs. 75 each for the two shops bearing Nos. 12 and 14 respectively, Godown Street, Bangalore City in their actual occupation and by attornment of the other properties in the occupation of the other tenants.

facts.text: On the judgment-debtors or their nominees tendering the decree amount within one year from the date of the decree, the decree-holders bind themselves to reconvey the properties.

anchor.surface_text: That on the judgment-debtors or their numberinees tendering the aforesaid decree amount through companyrt or otherwise within the aforesaid one year from the date of the decree, the decrce-holders bind themselves to reconvey the properties which are sold to them under this rajinama at their companyt

facts.text: Time is essence of the contract for reconveyance.

anchor.surface_text: provided it is distinctly agreed that time is essence of the companytract

facts.text: If judgment-debtors default in paying rents on or before the 15th of any month they lose the concession of reconveyance within one year.

anchor.surface_text: provided also that if the judgment-debtors default in paying the rents as aforesaid on or before the 15th of any month they will lose the companycession hereby offered to thee of having reconveyance of the properties in one years time.

facts.text: Attachment on properties of 2nd and 3rd defendants obtained before judgment stands raised.

anchor.surface_text: Attachment on the properties belonging to the 2nd and 3rd defendants obtained before judgment stands hereby raised.

facts.text: The appellants did not execute a regular sale-deed within ten days from September 30, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: It would be numbericed that under the second sentence of cl. 2 the appellants had to execute a regular sale-deed within ten days from September 30, 1955. They, however, did number do so

facts.text: On October 31, 1955, the respondents filed Interlocutory Application No. 6 of 1955, later numbered as Execution Application No. 83 of 1956, for directing the appellants to execute the sale-deed and annexed a draft sale-deed.

anchor.surface_text: and thereupon the respondents filed, on October 31, 1955, Interlocutory application No. 6 of 1955  later numbered as Execution Application No. 83 of 1956  for directing the appellants to execute the sale-deed and they annexed to their application a draft sale-deed in which cls. 3 to 6 of the razmama were recited.

facts.text: There were disputes between the parties each accusing the other of not conforming to its undertaking under the compromise.

anchor.surface_text: Apparently there were disputes between the parties each accusing the other that it had number companyformed to its undertaking under the companypromise, but with these we are number number companycerned.

facts.text: On March 16, 1956, the appellants filed an application in the suit praying that a sale-deed might be executed in favour of a third party who agreed to purchase the property by paying the full decree-amount as per cl. 4 of the Razinama.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the appellants filed an application in the suit on March 16, 1956, praying that a sale-deed might be executed in favour of a third party to the proceedings who had agreed to purchase the property on terms of paying the full decree-amount as provided for by cl. 4 of the Razinama.

facts.text: The appellants' application was opposed by the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: This application was opposed by the respondents

facts.text: The learned District Judge of Bangalore upheld the appellants' objection and rejected the respondents' prayer for directing execution of sale-deed.

anchor.surface_text: This objection was upheld by the learned District judge of Bangalore and the prayer of the respondents for directing the appellants to execute a sale-deed in their favour was rejected.

facts.text: The Mysore High Court reversed the District Judge's order on appeal by the respondents in R.A. No. 268 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: This order has been reversed by the learned judges of the High Court on appeal by the respondents

facts.text: The appeal to Supreme Court comes on a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court under Art. 133 (1) (a) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: and it is the companyrectness of this judgment that is canvassed in this appeal which companyes before us on a certificate of fitness granted by the High Court under Art. 133  1  a  of the Constitution.

facts.text: It is common ground that the decree embodied the entire razinama including all its terms.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the decree embodied the entire razinama including all its terms.

facts.text: There is no dispute that the agreement was lawful and an executable decree could be passed so far as it related to the suit.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that the agreement was lawful and an executable decree companyld-be passed so far as it related to the suit.

facts.text: The High Court directed execution of clause 2 of the compromise decree and expressed no opinion on executability of other clauses.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges expressed themselves thus The decree-holder is entitled to execute the decree in respect of clause 2 of the companypromise. No opinion is expressed as to the executability of the other clauses of the companypromise as that question has number been raised before us.

facts.text: The question of inter-relation between cl. 2 and cls. 3 to 6 or entitlement to reconveyance was not raised before the High Court.

concepts.unlisted_description: Decree on compromise or adjustment of suit

anchor.surface_text: The relevant statutory provision for the passing of decrees by companypromise is O. XXIII, r. 3, Code of Civil Procedure, which runs Where it is proved to the satisfaction of the Court that a suit has been adjusted wholly or in part by any lawful agreement or companypromise, or where the defendant satisfies the plaintiff in respect of the whole or any part of the subject-matter of the suit, the Court shall order such agreement, companypromise or satisfaction to be recorded and shall pass a decree in accordance therewith, so far as it relates to the suit.

concepts.interpretation: Court applied to hold that clause 2 of compromise (sale of mortgaged properties) relates to the suit as properties were mortgaged and liable to sale in execution, sale price equals decretal amount, and conveyance is consideration for compromise; thus executable in execution proceedings.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: part of the decree, an objection as to the executability of any particular term companyld be raised in execution proceedings, but shall proceed on the

concepts.unlisted_description: Decree on compromise or adjustment of suit

anchor.surface_text: the import of the expression so far as it relates to the suit occurring in r. 3

concepts.interpretation: Courts below argued over 'so far as it relates to the suit'; SC agreed with High Court that compromise terms related to suit; no emphasis needed as clear.

issues.text: whether the High Court was justified in directing the appellants to execute a sale-deed conveying the suit properties to the respondents in the proceedings in execution of the decree in original suit No. 29 of 1954 or whether the respondents could obtain that relief only in an independent suit instituted for that purpose

anchor.surface_text: It would be seen from this narration that the point involved in the appeal is very narrow and turns on the question whether the High Court was justified in directing the appellants to execute a sale-deed conveying the suit properties to the respondents in the proceedings in execution of the decree in original suit No. 29 of 1954 or whether the respondents could obtain that relief only in an independent suit instituted for that purpose.

issues.text: the question raised in this appeal relates to the executability of cl. 2 of this compromise decree

anchor.surface_text: Broadly stated, the question raised in this appeal relates to the executability of cl. 2 of this companypromise decree but before examining this companytention it is necessary to state a few facts. It would be noticed that under the second sentence of cl. 2 the appellants had to execute a regular sale-deed within ten days from September 30, 1955.

issues.text: whether the terms of the compromise related to the suit so far as it relates to the suit under O. XXIII r. 3

anchor.surface_text: Though in the courts below most of the argument turned on the import of the expression so far as it relates to the suit occurring in r. 3, learned Counsel for the appellants did not stress that contention before us, but rather on the construction of the several clauses of the compromise and their inter-relation to which we shall advert presently.

issues.text: whether, when a decree has been passed embodying all the terms as part of the decree, an objection as to the executability of any particular term could be raised in execution proceedings

anchor.surface_text: We do not having regard to the facts of this case, consider it necessary to examine the position whether, when a decree has been passed embodying all the terms as part of the decree, an objection as to the executability of any particular term could be raised in execution proceedings, but shall proceed on the basis that it could be.

issues.text: on a proper construction of the compromise, whether the consideration therefor was the actual execution of the conveyance by the judgment debtor to the decree-holder but merely the agreement to execute such a conveyance and whether the decree was satisfied immediately upon filing the memo of compromise

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the appellants however raised before us two contentions in the alternative. His first and primary contention was that on a proper construction of the compromise, the consideration therefor was not the actual execution of the conveyance by the judgment debtor to the decree-holder but merely the agreement to execute such a conveyance.

issues.text: whether the learned judges should have directed the execution of a conveyance in favour of the respondents without attaching to it the conditions laid down in cls. 3 to 6 and without an examination of the question whether the appellants were entitled to enforce the reconveyance provided by those clauses

anchor.surface_text: The other submission of learned Counsel was that the learned judges should not have directed the execution of a conveyance in favour of the respondents without attaching to it the conditions laid down in cls. 3 to 6 and also without an examination of the question whether the appellants were entitled to enforce the reconveyance provided by those clauses.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the appellants filed an application in the suit on March 16, 1956, praying that a sale-deed might be executed in favour of a third party to the proceedings who had agreed to purchase the property on terms of paying the full decree-amount as provided for by cl. 4 of the Razinama.

holdings.text: The learned Judges were right in the view they took that the terms of the compromise related to the suit.

anchor.surface_text: We might, however, point out that the learned Judges were right in the view they took that the terms of the compromise related to the suit. The property which was to be conveyed consisted entirely of property included in the mortgage and which was therefore liable to be sold in execution of the mortgage decree which was the relief sought in the plaint.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Property consisted of mortgaged properties liable to sale in execution; sale price equal to decretal amount; conveyance was consideration for compromise.

holdings.text: When a decree embodies all terms of compromise, an objection to executability of particular term could be raised in execution proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: We do not having regard to the facts of this case, consider it necessary to examine the position whether, when a decree has been passed embodying all the terms as part of the decree, an objection as to the executability of any particular term could be raised in execution proceedings, but shall proceed on the basis that it could be.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not necessary to examine given facts of case; proceed on assumption that such objection could be raised.

holdings.text: On proper construction of compromise, consideration was actual execution of conveyance by judgment-debtor, not mere agreement; decree not satisfied on filing memo of compromise.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves wholly unable to accept this argument. No doubt under cl 1 there, was to be a simple mortgage decree as prayed for in the suit, but it would, however, not be a proper construction of the 1st sentence of cl. 2 to say that the mere agreement to, convey and not an actual conveyance was intended to operate as a satisfaction of the decree passed or to be passed under cl.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.1 provides for mortgage decree; cl.2 states properties 'hereby sold' implying actual conveyance for satisfaction; mere agreement insufficient despite integrated scheme in cls.2-6.

holdings.text: High Court did not err in directing execution of clause 2 without considering clauses 3-6 as those questions not raised before it.

anchor.surface_text: The fact, therefore, was that this point about either the inter-relation between cl. 2 on the one hand and cls. 3 to 6 on the other or the contention of the appellants that they were entitled to relief under cls. 3 to 6 was not raised before the High Court and the matter was therefore left open.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inter-relation of clauses and entitlement to reconveyance not raised before High Court; no opinion expressed on executability of other clauses; factual issues require investigation not suitable for Supreme Court.

holdings.text: Decree-holder entitled to execute decree in respect of clause 2 of compromise.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges expressed themselves thus The decree-holder is entitled to execute the decree in respect of clause 2 of the compromise. No opinion is expressed as to the executability of the other clauses of the compromise as that question has not been raised before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirming High Court; clause 2 relates to suit and executable; upholds direction for execution of sale-deed.

anchor.surface_text: The other submission of learned Counsel was that the learned judges should number have directed the execution of a companyveyance in favour of the respondents without attaching to it the companyditions laid down in cls. 3 to 6 and also without an examination of the question whether the appellants were entitled to enforce the reconveyance provided by those clauses. On this matter the learned Judges expressed themselves thus The decree-holder is entitled to execute the decree in respect of clause 2 of the companypromise. No opinion is expressed as to the executability of the other clauses of the companypromise as that question has number been raised before us. The fact, therefore, was that this point about either the inter-relation between cl. 2 on the one hand and cls. 3 to 6 on the other or the companytention of the appellants that they were entitled to relief under cls. 3 to 6 was number raised before the High Court and the matter was therefore left open.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order allowing execution of clause 2 of compromise decree upheld; appellants' objections rejected
directions: Appellants may agitate their rights under clauses 3 to 6 in appropriate proceedings if so advised

anchor.surface_text: The other submission of learned Counsel was that the learned judges should number have directed the execution of a companyveyance in favour of the respondents without attaching to it the companyditions laid down in cls. 3 to 6 and also without an examination of the question whether the appellants were entitled to enforce the reconveyance provided by those clauses. On this matter the learned Judges expressed themselves thus The decree-holder is entitled to execute the decree in respect of clause 2 of the companypromise. No opinion is expressed as to the executability of the other clauses of the companypromise as that question has number been raised before us. The fact, therefore, was that this point about either the inter-relation between cl. 2 on the one hand and cls. 3 to 6 on the other or the companytention of the appellants that they were entitled to relief under cls. 3 to 6 was number raised before the High Court and the matter was therefore left open.

We do not having regard to the facts of this case, consider it necessary to examine the position whether, when a decree has been passed embodying all the terms as part of the decree, an objection as to the executability of any particular term could be raised in execution proceedings, but shall proceed on the basis that it could be.

We find ourselves wholly unable to accept this argument. No doubt under cl 1 there, was to be a simple mortgage decree as prayed for in the suit, but it would, however, not be a proper construction of the 1st sentence of cl. 2 to say that the mere agreement to, convey and not an actual conveyance was intended to operate as a satisfaction of the decree passed or to be passed under cl.

The other submission of learned Counsel was that the learned judges should number have directed the execution of a companyveyance in favour of the respondents without attaching to it the companyditions laid down in cls. 3 to 6 and also without an examination of the question whether the appellants were entitled to enforce the reconveyance provided by those clauses. On this matter the learned Judges expressed themselves thus The decree-holder is entitled to execute the decree in respect of clause 2 of the companypromise. No opinion is expressed as to the executability of the other clauses of the companypromise as that question has number been raised before us. The fact, therefore, was that this point about either the inter-relation between cl. 2 on the one hand and cls. 3 to 6 on the other or the companytention of the appellants that they were entitled to relief under cls. 3 to 6 was number raised before the High Court and the matter was therefore left open.

The fact, therefore, was that this point about either the inter-relation between cl. 2 on the one hand and cls. 3 to 6 on the other or the contention of the appellants that they were entitled to relief under cls. 3 to 6 was not raised before the High Court and the matter was therefore left open.

The other submission of learned Counsel was that the learned judges should number have directed the execution of a companyveyance in favour of the respondents without attaching to it the companyditions laid down in cls. 3 to 6 and also without an examination of the question whether the appellants were entitled to enforce the reconveyance provided by those clauses. On this matter the learned Judges expressed themselves thus The decree-holder is entitled to execute the decree in respect of clause 2 of the companypromise. No opinion is expressed as to the executability of the other clauses of the companypromise as that question has number been raised before us. The fact, therefore, was that this point about either the inter-relation between cl. 2 on the one hand and cls. 3 to 6 on the other or the companytention of the appellants that they were entitled to relief under cls. 3 to 6 was number raised before the High Court and the matter was therefore left open.
